greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Smallest prime p such that there exist exactly n integers b such that 1 < b < p and b^(p-1) == 1 (mod p^2) or, equivalently, Fermat quotient q_p(b) == 0 (mod p).
comment: a(n) is the smallest prime p such that A242830(PrimePi(p)) = n, PrimePi = A000720. - _Jianing Song_, Jan 27 2019
example: a(5) = 653 since 653 is the smallest prime with exactly five bases b = 84, 120, 197, 287, 410.
program: (PARI) first_n_entries(n)=v=vector(n); toGo=n; forprime(p=2, , count=sum(b=2, p-1, Mod(b, p^2)^(p-1)==1); if(count<=(n-1)&!v[count+1], v[count+1]=p; toGo--; if(!toGo, return(v)))) \\ _Jeppe Stig Nielsen_, Jul 31 2015, changed to include a(0) = 2 by _Jianing Song_, Feb 05 2019
results.author: _Max Alekseyev_, Oct 24 2010
